inlineContent.text: A text view draws a string in your app’s user interface using a
font that’s appropriate for the current platform. You can
choose a different standard font, like
or
using the
view modifier.
If you need finer control over the styling of the text, you can use the same
modifier to configure a system font or choose a custom font. You can also
apply view modifiers like
or
to further
adjust the formatting.
To apply styling within specific portions of the text, you can create
the text view from an
which in turn allows you to use Markdown to style runs of text. You can
mix string attributes and SwiftUI modifiers, with the string attributes
taking priority.
A text view always uses exactly the amount of space it needs to display its
rendered contents, but you can affect the view’s layout. For example, you
can use the
modifier to propose
specific dimensions to the view. If the view accepts the proposal but the
text doesn’t fit into the available space, the view uses a combination of
wrapping, tightening, scaling, and truncation to make it fit. With a width
of
points but no constraint on the height, a text view might wrap a
long string:

code: Text("To be, or not to be, that is the question:")

inlineContent.text: Use modifiers like
, and
to
configure how the view handles space constraints. For example, combining a
fixed width and a line limit of
results in truncation for text that
doesn’t fit in that space:

code: Text("Brevity is the soul of wit.")

inlineContent.text: If you initialize a text view with a string literal, the view uses the
initializer, which interprets the
string as a localization key and searches for the key in the table you
specify, or in the default table if you don’t specify one.

code: Text("pencil") // Searches the default table in the main bundle.

inlineContent.text: For an app localized in both English and Spanish, the above view displays
“pencil” and “lápiz” for English and Spanish users, respectively. If the
view can’t perform localization, it displays the key instead. For example,
if the same app lacks Danish localization, the view displays “pencil” for
users in that locale. Similarly, an app that lacks any localization
information displays “pencil” in any locale.
To explicitly bypass localization for a string literal, use the
initializer.

code: Text(verbatim: "pencil") // Displays the string "pencil" in any locale.

inlineContent.text: If you initialize a text view with a variable value, the view uses the
initializer, which doesn’t localize the string. However,
you can request localization by creating a
instance
first, which triggers the
initializer instead:

code: // ...unless you explicitly convert it to a localized string key.

inlineContent.text: When localizing a string variable, you can use the default table by omitting
the optional initialization parameters — as in the above example — just like
you might for a string literal.
When composing a complex string, where there is a need to assemble multiple
pieces of text, use string interpolation:
This would look up the
localization key in the localized
string file and replace the format specifier
with the value of
before rendering the text on screen.
Using string interpolation ensures that the text in your app can be localized
correctly in all locales, especially in right-to-left languages.
If you desire to style only parts of interpolated text while ensuring that
the content can still be localized correctly, interpolate
or
The example above uses
and will look up the
in the localized string file and
interpolate a bold text rendering the value of
Using
you can interpolate
in text.

abstract.text: A view that displays one or more lines of read-only text.
Applies a bold or emphasized treatment to the fonts of the text.
A value type for a string with associated attributes for portions of its text.
Sets whether VoiceOver should speak the contents of the text view
character by character.
Sets to a closed range the number of lines that text can occupy in
this view.
Modifies the text view’s font to use fixed-width digits, while leaving
other characters proportionally spaced.
Appends the string displayed by a text view to a string
interpolation.
A view that displays one or more lines of read-only text.
Positions this view within an invisible frame with the specified size.
A scheme for transforming the capitalization of characters within text.
Bundle view modifiers that you regularly reuse into a custom view modifier.
Creates a text view that displays localized content identified by a key.
Sets the default font for text in this view.
Sets the font weight of the text.
Sets the default font for text in the view.
The key used to look up an entry in a strings file or strings dictionary
file.
A type that represents part of your app’s user interface and provides
modifiers that you use to configure views.
Create a view layout by adjusting the size of views.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
Visualize collections of data with platform-appropriate appearance.
Applies a text scale to the text.
Creates an instance that displays localized dates and times using a specific style.
Provide suggestions to people searching for content in your app.
Creates a text view that displays the formatted representation
of a nonstring type supported by a corresponding format style.
Sets the tracking for the text.
Applies an underline to the text.
Sets the style for labels within this view.
Sets the accessibility level of this heading.
A standard label for user interface items, consisting of an icon with a
title.
A font with the title text style.
Creates a text view that displays a string literal without localization.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.

A type whose metatype can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races. When a generic type `T` conforms to `SendableMetatype`, its metatype `T.Type` conforms to `Sendable`.  All concrete types implicitly conform to the `SendableMetatype` protocol, so its primary purpose is in generic code to prohibit the use of isolated conformances along with the generic type.
The type of truncation to apply to a line of text when it’s too long to
fit in the available space.

Controls whether to queue pending announcements behind existing speech
rather than interrupting speech in progress.
